questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider because of headaches that began five-months ago. The patient reports that the headaches are worse in the morning and improve over the day. In addition, the patient endorses reduced body hair. He does not use any medications. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg. Physical exam is notable for restricted peripheral vision and white watery discharge from the nipples. Further review of the patient’s history will most likely reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has prolactinoma (also termed lactotroph adenoma), a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma. In men, it can cause infertility, erectile dysfunction, reduced facial and body hair, and galactorrhea. Patients may also experience symptoms secondary to mass effect. These include headache, vomiting, and bitemporal hemianopsia, due to compression of the optic chiasm by the mass.

Women with prolactinomas also experience galactorrhea, infertility, and mass effect. However, women may also develop amenorrhea, vaginal dryness, and osteoporosis because prolactin suppresses hypothalamic production of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). Reduced GnRH production reduces the secretion of estrogens, ultimately resulting in impaired ovulatory cycles and increased osteoclast bone resorption.



Option Analysis

❌ Skin hyperpigmentation:
Incorrect: Hyperpigmentation is usually seen in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency, in which deficiency of cortisol increases the secretion of ACTH by the negative-feedback mechanism. ACTH and melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) are derived from the same precursor molecule. As a result, increased ACTH production will also lead to increased MSH production. However, adrenal insufficiency does not typically cause white nipple discharge.
❌ Kidney stones:
Incorrect: Patients with hyperparathyroidism often develop hypercalcemia and kidney stones. Severe hypercalcemia can cause headaches. However, the findings of reduced body hair, nipple discharge and bitemporal hemianopsia make prolactinoma more likely.
✅ Erectile dysfunction:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Diffuse muscle atrophy:
Incorrect: Muscle atrophy is usually seen in patients with hypercortisolism. Although an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma would explain the headaches and visual deficits, the condition is usually associated with ecchymosis, abdominal striae, fat redistribution, and/or hypertension, none of which are seen in this patient.
❌ Enlarged head with frontal bossing:
Incorrect: This finding is seen in patients with acromegaly, a condition caused by a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma. Though it can present with headaches and visual disturbances due to mass effect, patients with acromegaly also have macrognathia, widened hands and feet and/or osteoarthritis. In contrast, the patient in this vignette lacks any of these findings.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parent due to abnormal body movements. His parent states that the patient has been walking abnormally for the past several weeks with frequent falls. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals multidirectional, nonrhythmic eye movements. The patient is also observed to have sporadic limb jerkings and truncal ataxia when walking. A left-sided immobile abdominal mass is palpated. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory testing reveals anemia, and elevated levels of homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid are detected in the urine. The abdominal mass most likely originated from which of the following embryologic derivatives?
questions.solution:
This young boy is presenting with an abdominal mass, opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome, and elevated urinary catecholamine metabolites. He most likely has a neuroblastoma. Neuroblastomas are malignant tumors of the sympathetic nervous system. They are composed of poorly differentiated “neuroblasts,” which originate from the neural crest, and they can occur anywhere in the sympathetic chain or adrenal medulla.

A classic paraneoplastic syndrome called the opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia (OMA) syndrome, or “dancing eye syndrome,” can be present in some patients. This syndrome is a neurological disorder consisting of three main symptoms: 1) opsoclonus, which are multidirectional, chaotic eye movements, 2) myoclonus, which are nonepileptic limb jerkings that can also involve the head and face, and 3) truncal ataxia, which causes gait imbalance. Almost 50% of children with OMA syndrome have an underlying neuroblastoma; therefore all children presenting with OMA syndrome should be evaluated for neuroblastoma.





Option Analysis

✅ Neural crest:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Endoderm:
Incorrect: The endoderm gives rise to all structures derived from the inner lining of the primitive gut tube. Organs such as the stomach, liver, and intestines all arise from the endoderm. Although this patient is presenting with an abdominal mass, another embryologic derivative gives rise to neuroblastomas.
❌ Mesoderm:
Incorrect: The mesoderm gives rise to bones, muscles, visceral tissues, and many organs (e.g., kidneys, adrenal cortex, testes, ovaries). Although a Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) can present as an abdominal mass, this patient’s opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome is more consistent with the presentation of a neuroblastoma.
❌ Neuroectoderm:
Incorrect: The neuroectoderm gives rise to the central nervous system and preganglionic autonomic neurons. It is not, however, the origin of neuroblastoma.
❌ Surface ectoderm:
Incorrect: The surface ectoderm gives rise to the outer layer of many organs (e.g., lens of eye, epithelial linings of oral cavity), as well as the sweat and mammary glands. Additionally, it is the origin of craniopharyngiomas in children, which present as an anterior pituitary mass. However, the surface ectoderm is not the origin of neuroblastomas, which classically present with the opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for voice changes after thyroid surgery. The patient was diagnosed with papillary thyroid cancer and subsequently underwent thyroidectomy. Immediately after the surgery, she noticed some mild voice changes, but the doctor informed her that this is usually transient due to local edema and will likely self-resolve. Currently, the patient describes only mild voice and pitch changes but denies any dysphagia. On physical examination, sensation of the mucosa above the glottis is intact. After evaluation, the doctor suspects an isolated unilateral paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle. Which of the following nerves demonstrated in the picture below was most likely injured during the surgery?
questions.solution:
This patient has mild voice changes without dysphagia following thyroidectomy, which raises concern for iatrogenic nerve injury caused by surgery. Complications during thyroid surgery are common and may include hematoma/wound seroma, hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism, hoarseness, voice changes, vocal cord paralysis, Horner syndrome, chyle fistula, tracheal and esophageal injuries, and dysphagia.  

The laryngeal nerves are at risk for injury during thyroid surgery. The vagus nerve gives rise to a branch named the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) about 4 cm above the carotid bifurcation. The SLN then divides into the internal laryngeal nerve and external laryngeal nerve. The internal branch supplies sensory innervation to the supraglottic region, whereas the external branch carries motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle. Damage to the external branch may occur during ligation of the superior thyroid artery. External laryngeal nerve injury impairs the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for abduction and opening of the rima glottis by rotating the arytenoid cartilage laterally. Patients may experience vocal fatigue and subtle voice changes.  

After branching into the SLN, the vagus nerves continue caudally and give rise to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN). The RLN innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid as well as sensation below the vocal cord. These muscles function to adduct the vocal cords and close the rima glottis. RLN injury can occur during ligation of the inferior thyroid artery. Since the RLN innervates the majority of the intrinsic laryngeal muscles, its damage results in more severe symptoms. These include respiratory obstruction, hoarseness, inability to speak, and loss of sensation below the vocal cord.  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This is the superior laryngeal nerve which splits into the internal and external laryngeal nerves. Injury in this location will result in both unilateral paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle (external laryngeal nerve) and sensation deficit (internal laryngeal nerve) above the vocal cord. The patient has intact sensation.
❌ B:
Incorrect: This is the internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Injury in that location will result in a sensory deficit above the vocal cord. The patient has intact sensation.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: This is the recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve. Injury in this location will result in severe hoarseness and dysphagia due to paralysis of the posterior cricoarytenoid, lateral cricoarytenoid, oblique arytenoid, transverse arytenoid, and thyroarytenoid muscles. This patient has only mild symptoms, which favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to a surgeon after her primary care physician noticed a lump in her neck. A biopsy is performed, and the samples are sent to pathology for analysis, revealing follicular thyroid cancer. The patient is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. During the operation, a nerve near the superior thyroid artery is injured. Which of the following structures was most likely injured?

choices.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
Pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve

questions.solution:
The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve travels close to the superior thyroid artery and can be easily injured in thyroid surgeries.  

The superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. It subsequently divides into the external and internal branches. The external branch supplies the cricothyroid muscle and helps tense the vocal cords. This branch travels along the lateral surface of the inferior constrictor muscle of the pharynx and closely follows the superior thyroid artery. As a result, it is susceptible to injury during thyroidectomy. The resultant neurological effects include ipsilateral anesthesia of the larynx above the level of the vocal cords and paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle. Most cases of unilateral paralysis are asymptomatic. However, symptomatic patients may experience a weak voice, occasional hoarseness, and voice quality and pitch changes.  



The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the supraglottic larynx. This branch enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane and courses relatively far from the thyroid. As a result, it is not typically injured in thyroidectomy. However, the superior laryngeal nerve as a whole can be damaged during skull base surgery, resulting in a loss of sensation of the superior laryngeal mucosa.   

Option Analysis

✅ External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve :
Incorrect: The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane. The nerve does not course near the thyroid and, as a result, is not commonly injured during thyroidectomies. 
❌ The recurrent laryngeal nerve :
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve can be injured during thyroidectomies when dissecting the inferior thyroid artery due to their proximity. However, the nerve injured in this patient courses near the superior thyroid artery.
❌ Accessory nerve:
Incorrect: The accessory nerve is not susceptible to injury during thyroidectomies. 
❌ Pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve :
Incorrect: The pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve are not susceptible to injury during thyroidectomies.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for an evaluation of hoarseness. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy for treatment of thyroid carcinoma one month ago and subsequently developed hoarseness of the voice. Initially, she thought the symptom was just a transient side effect of the operation. However, when the symptoms persisted, she decided to seek further medical care. Vitals are within normal limits. The strength and sensation of the head and neck are intact. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Direct laryngoscopy reveals paralysis of the right vocal cord. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery
Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery
Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery.
Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery
Injury to the right internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hoarseness and unilateral vocal cord paralysis following a thyroidectomy. These findings are most likely due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury during intraoperative dissection of the inferior thyroid artery.  

The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is a branch of the vagus nerve. The RLN innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle, which is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. The recurrent laryngeal nerve also provides sensory supply to the larynx below the level of the vocal cords (subglottic sensation) and motor supply to the vocal cords.  

The right RLN descends with the rest of the vagus nerve anterior to the right subclavian artery before branching off and winding back around it posteriorly to course cranially in the tracheoesophageal groove toward the larynx. The right laryngeal nerve courses closely with the inferior thyroid artery at the junction of the lower and middle thirds of the thyroid. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve courses with the vagus nerve before branching and winding posteriorly around the aortic arch, subsequently ascending through the superior mediastinum and the tracheoesophageal groove towards the larynx. Both branches of the recurrent laryngeal nerve then enter the larynx below the inferior constrictor to supply the muscles and mucosa of the larynx.  

 


During a total thyroidectomy, patients are at risk of developing unilateral or bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis. Unilateral injury can cause paralysis to the true vocal cord and intrinsic muscles of the larynx. Clinically, patients can present with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve can cause stridor, airway compromise, and respiratory distress. It may necessitate a tracheostomy.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery:
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the inferior thyroid artery, not the superior thyroid artery. 
❌ Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery. :
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery. This nerve is responsible for supplying the cricothyroid muscle of the larynx. Damage to this nerve may cause changes to the pitch of a patient’s voice. However, vocal cord paralysis is more suggestive of recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery:
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery, not the inferior thyroid artery. Injury to this nerve may cause changes to the pitch of a patient’s voice. However, vocal cord paralysis is more suggestive of recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Injury to the right internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery :
Incorrect: The internal branch provides sensory supply to the mucosa of the supraglottic larynx. It enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane and courses relatively far from the thyroid. As a result, it is not typically injured in thyroidectomy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is currently postoperative day two in the surgical intensive care unit post total thyroidectomy for anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. During rounds, the patient reports a sensation of numbness around her lips and mouth and intermittent twitching of her upper and lower extremities. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 156/67 mmHg, and O2. is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an intact incision over the anterior neck without edema or erythema.  A routine electrocardiogram is demonstrated below.  Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be present based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after total thyroidectomy with findings of circumoral numbness, tetany, and a prolonged QT interval on routine electrocardiographic screening, consistent with hypocalcemia. In the setting of a recent thyroidectomy, the most likely etiology of hypocalcemia is removal or damage to the parathyroid glands, resulting in hypoparathyroidism. The laboratory findings most reflective of this clinical condition is choice A.  

Multiple structures are at risk of injury during thyroidectomy or hemithyroidectomy, including surrounding glands, vasculature, and nerves (e.g., recurrent laryngeal nerves, external branches of the superior laryngeal nerves). Injury to the parathyroid glands can produce transient or permanent hypoparathyroidism. For this reason, many patients undergoing this procedure are empirically prescribed calcium supplementation to avoid complications associated with hypocalcemia.    

Symptoms of hypoparathyroidism and associated hypocalcemia include muscle tetany, paresthesias, seizures, and psychiatric symptoms (e.g., emotional instability, anxiety, depression). Moreover, hypocalcemia can cause cardiovascular compromise, resulting in QT interval prolongation on ECG, which can degenerate into torsade de pointes. Physical exam findings include the Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign (carpal spasms triggered by inflation of a sphygmomanometer).  

Option Analysis

✅                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↑  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↑  ↑:
Incorrect: Secondary hypoparathyroidism, due to chronic kidney disease, manifests with decreased levels of calcium, increased levels of phosphate, and increased parathyroid hormone. These effects are secondary to the kidney’s inability to respond to parathyroid hormone appropriately. 
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↓ ↑:
Incorrect: Vitamin D deficiency is characterized by decreased calcium, decreased phosphate, and increased parathyroid hormone levels.
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are not consistent with calcium, phosphorus, and parathyroid hormone homeostasis disorders. 
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↑  ↑  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are not consistent with calcium, phosphorus, or parathyroid hormone homeostasis disorders.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman undergoes a total thyroidectomy due to the presence of follicular thyroid cancer. On a postoperative day one, the patient develops a hoarse, breathy voice. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination demonstrates an intact postoperative incision without erythema or edema over the anterior neck. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Several structures are at risk of iatrogenic injury in patients undergoing thyroidectomy and hemithyroidectomy. One of the structures at risk of injury is the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN).  Unilateral injury presents as temporary or permanent hoarseness and risk of aspiration (especially with liquids). In contrast, bilateral injury causes stridor and acute airway obstruction as the recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies the only abductor of the vocal cords, the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle.  The paired recurrent laryngeal nerves branch off the vagus nerve and travel in the tracheoesophageal groove until they enter the larynx at the cricothyroid joint. The RLN supplies innervation to all of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, minus the cricothyroid muscles, as well as sensation to the larynx below the level of the vocal cords.

In addition to the RLN, several additional structures are at risk of injury during thyroidectomy, including the parathyroid glands, superior laryngeal nerve (SLN), vagus nerve, thyroid ima artery, and common carotid arteries (and their local branches). Injury to the vascular structures often results in hematoma/seroma formation and brisk bleeding intraoperatively. Injury to the SLN manifests as vocal fatigue and subtle changes in voice quality, pitch, and projection (in contrast to true hoarseness with RLN injury). Injury to the vagus nerve may result in the larynx's sensory and motor deficits.

Option Analysis

✅ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Isolated superior laryngeal nerve injury only produces vocal fatigue and subtle changes in voice quality involving timbre, pitch, and voice projection. This patient presents with vocal cord paralysis.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. When injured during head and neck procedures, it can be a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: Injury to the common carotid artery results in hematoma formation and possible neurologic deficits secondary to ischemic or thromboembolic events.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis of both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve. This can result in both sensory and motor deficits of the larynx. Injury to the main trunk of the vagus nerve is rare during thyroid surgery.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the office due to a neck lump. The patient reports no symptoms, weight loss, dysphagia, or voice changes. She does not use tobacco, excessive alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. On physical examination, there is a fixed non-tender nodule in the left thyroid lobe. Serum TSH is within normal limits, and ultrasound shows a 2.5 cm solid mass. A fine-needle biopsy is obtained and shows varying degrees of follicles and microfollicles. A decision is made to perform thyroid lobectomy. Which of the following pathohistological findings will confirm the diagnosis of follicular thyroid cancer?

choices.text: Pink material with Congo red stain

questions.solution:
This patient has a fixed, non-tender thyroid nodule and normal TSH levels, which raises concern for malignancy. The fine needle aspiration shows varying degrees of normal follicles, which can indicate follicular adenoma or follicular carcinoma. The only way to distinguish follicular carcinoma from adenoma is by demonstrating capsular invasion after surgical excision of the entire lesion.  

Follicular thyroid carcinoma accounts for 12% of all cases of thyroid cancers. Peak incidence is between ages 40 and 60 years and 3 times more common in women. Risk factors include a history of radiation exposure during childhood, thyroid cancer in a first-degree relative, or positive family history of a thyroid cancer syndrome. The condition is associated with RAS mutations and PAX8-PPAR-γ translocations.  

Many cases are discovered incidentally on routine physical exams or radiologic imaging. The histologic features vary from normal, well-differentiated follicles and colloid (good prognosis) to poorly differentiated solid growth, with an absence of follicles, nuclear atypia, and extensive vascular and/or capsular invasion (poor prognosis). Follicular thyroid cancer is unique to carcinomas as it exclusively spreads via hematogenous dissemination (usually lymphatic spread). A definitive diagnosis requires histologic evaluation after surgery and the identification of tumor capsule and/or vascular invasion, since a fine-needle aspiration cannot properly observe the capsule.  

Option Analysis

❌ Concentric calcifications:
Incorrect: This finding is consistent with psammoma bodies, a unique finding of papillary thyroid carcinoma. Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer. On histology, it is characterized by cells with nuclear clearing (“Orphan Annie eye”) and nuclear grooves.
❌ Hürthle cells:
Incorrect: Hürthle cells, or oxyphil cells, are large polyclonal cells with abundant oxyphilic cytoplasm. These cells can be seen in a variety of conditions including Hürthle cell adenoma and carcinomas, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, and Hashimoto thyroiditis. While Hürthle cell carcinomas were previously thought to be a variant of follicular thyroid cancer, they are not characteristic of classic follicular thyroid cancer.
❌ Pink material with Congo red stain:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with medullary carcinoma, a parafollicular “C-cell” tumor that produces calcitonin. On histology, it appears as sheets of cells in an amyloid stroma, which turn red when stained with Congo red.
❌ Marked nuclear atypia:
Incorrect: Nuclear atypia, which refers to the abnormal appearance of the cell nucleus, can be seen in reactive changes, pre-neoplastic changes, or malignancy. Marked nuclear atypia is, in most cases, considered an important indicator of malignancy. However, the finding is nonspecific and would not confirm the diagnosis of follicular thyroid cancer.
✅ Capsular invasion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman comes to the office due to a neck lump. She is otherwise healthy, and medical history is unremarkable. She does not use tobacco, excessive alcohol, or illicit substances. The patient has not noticed any weight loss, but she does endorse some changes in her voice lately. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a fixed, non-tender nodule occupying the right thyroid lobe. Laboratory testing shows normal TSH levels. Ultrasound is obtained and reveals a 2.5 cm, hypoechoic nodule with increased central flow. Fine-needle biopsy is performed and shows the following:

Wikimedia Commons

This finding can also be seen in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a non-tender, fixed thyroid nodule as well as vocal changes, which raises concern for a possible thyroid malignancy. The ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic nodule with increased central flow, indicating it is a vascular lesion and further increasing the suspicion that it is a malignant lesion. Finally, fine needle biopsy reveals a classic picture of thyroid papillary carcinoma with psammoma bodies and “Orphan Annie eyes.” There are 4 conditions associated with psammoma bodies, including meningiomas, papillary thyroid carcinoma, mesothelioma, and papillary serous carcinoma of the ovary and endometrium.  

Papillary thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid carcinoma (80% of cases). Exposure to ionizing radiation in childhood is a significant risk factor. Other risk factors include RET/PTC rearrangements and BRAF mutations. Histologically, the tumor is composed of papillae, which are finger-like projections. The cells lining the papillae contain central clearing of the nucleus (“Orphan Annie eyes”) and nuclear grooves (dark indentations within the nucleus). In addition, concentric calcifications termed psammoma bodies are often seen. The tumor usually spreads to cervical lymph nodes but carries a good prognosis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Ovarian carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sarcoidosis:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis is associated with granulomatous inflammation, a type of chronic inflammation that results in granuloma formation. A granuloma is a focus of epithelioid cells surrounded by multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes. This histological picture is consistent with psammoma bodies, not a granuloma.
❌ Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A:
Incorrect: Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A (MEN2A) is associated with parathyroid hyperplasia, medullary thyroid carcinoma (parafollicular C cells), and pheochromocytoma, none of which are associated with psammoma bodies.
❌ Schwannoma:
Incorrect: Schwannomas are tumors of Schwann cell origin that grow along the peripheral nerves, most commonly involving both cranial nerves VII and VIII. On histology, Schwannomas are positive for S-100 and are characterized by a biphasic architecture: Antoni A (dense hypercellular areas containing spindle cells) alternating with Antoni B (hypocellular myxoid areas). However, Schwannomas are not associated with psammoma bodies.
❌ Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung:
Incorrect: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is typically seen in patients who smoke, and it presents as a central mass. On histology, keratin pearls and intercellular bridges may be observed. However, it is not associated with psammoma bodies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office due to a neck mass. The patient first noticed it a few months ago while shaving, but he did not seek medical care at that time. He also describes worsening weakness, abdominal pain, and constipation. Medical history is insignificant other than appendectomy at age 16. On physical examination, a painless lump is noted on the left lobe of the thyroid. Multiple painless cervical lymph nodes are also noted. The rest of the physical examination is normal. TSH levels are within normal limits. PTH and calcium levels are elevated. Ultrasound is performed and reveals a solid and hypoechoic mass with microcalcifications. Which of the following features is most likely to be seen on fine-needle biopsy?

choices.text: Varying sizes of follicles filled with colloid
Crowded tall, columnar cells forming papillae without fibrovascular cores
Sheets of polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma
Cells with central clearing and interspersed concentric calcifications
Pleomorphic and spindle-shaped anaplastic cells invading local structures

questions.solution:
This patient has a painless thyroid nodule and enlarged lymph nodes, elevated PTH and calcium levels, constipation, and abdominal pain, as well as ultrasound findings suspicious for malignancy. This presentation is consistent with the diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A) syndrome, a hereditary condition presenting with parathyroid hyperplasia (hypercalcemia), medullary thyroid carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma. The abdominal pain and constipation are likely due to elevated calcium levels.  

Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor of the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland, which produce calcitonin. The majority of cases are sporadic, while the rest are hereditary as part of the MEN syndrome. In most cases of MTC, the disease has already metastasized by the time of diagnosis.  

Common presenting signs include detectable cervical lymph nodes, dysphagia, or hoarseness. Distant metastases may occur in the liver, lungs, bones, and less commonly the brain and skin. Serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) are elevated in MTC. MTC is associated with RET proto-oncogene mutations that result in constitutive activation of the RET tyrosine kinase receptor. On histology, the tumor is characterized by sheets of polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma that stains positive with Congo red.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Varying sizes of follicles filled with colloid:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with follicular carcinoma, a malignant proliferation of thyroid follicles. The same features can be seen in follicular adenoma. The only way to distinguish between follicular adenoma and carcinoma is to examine the surrounding capsule for signs of invasion. However, this patient is presenting with signs of hypercalcemia, which favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Crowded tall, columnar cells forming papillae without fibrovascular cores:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. However, Graves disease typically presents with signs of hyperthyroidism, including periorbital edema, exophthalmos, diarrhea, tachycardia, palpitations, dyspnea, and arrhythmias. Moreover, in Graves disease, TSH is likely to be low rather than normal.
✅ Sheets of polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cells with central clearing and interspersed concentric calcifications:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with papillary carcinoma, the most common type of thyroid cancer. On histology, it appears as papillae (finger-like projections) lined by cells with central clearing (“Orphan Annie eyes”) and nuclear grooves. Psammoma bodies, which are concentric calcifications, are also seen. However, this patient is presenting with signs of hypercalcemia, which favors another diagnosis.
❌ Pleomorphic and spindle-shaped anaplastic cells invading local structures:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with anaplastic carcinoma. This highly malignant and aggressive tumor, often seen in elderly patients, invades local structures and presents with compressive symptoms such as dysphagia, hoarseness, and respiratory compromise. This patient is young and has no signs of compression, which favors a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is referred to the clinic for the evaluation of a thyroid nodule. Medical history is significant for Hodgkin lymphoma as a teenager, for which she received radiation treatment. Temperature is 36°C (97.4°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows a 2cm x 2cm hard nodule on the right lobe of the thyroid gland. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasound imaging suggests a malignancy, and fine needle aspiration is performed. Fine needle aspiration is most likely to show which of the following pathological findings?

choices.text: Undifferentiated malignant cells invading local structures
Malignant cells in an amyloid stroma
Malignant proliferation of follicles that invade the capsule
Malignant cells with nuclear clearing and indentations
Normal cells with fibrosis that extend to local structures

questions.solution:
This patient, who has a history of exposure to ionizing radiation as a teenager, is now presenting with a suspicious thyroid nodule. She likely has papillary thyroid carcinoma. This is the most common type of thyroid cancer (80% of cases), and exposure to ionizing radiation in childhood is a significant risk factor. Additional risk factors include RET/PTC rearrangements and BRAF mutations. Histologically, the tumor is composed of papillae, which are finger-like projections. The cells lining the papillae contain central clearing of the nucleus, which is why they are referred to as “Orphan Annie eyes,” and nuclear grooves (dark indentations within the nucleus). In addition, concentric calcifications, termed psammoma bodies, are often seen. The tumor usually spreads to cervical lymph nodes but carries a good prognosis.


Option Analysis

❌ Undifferentiated malignant cells invading local structures:
Incorrect: Undifferentiated malignant cells invading local structures is characteristic of anaplastic carcinoma. This highly malignant aggressive tumor, often seen in elderly patients, invades local structures and presents with compressive symptoms such as dysphagia, hoarseness, and respiratory compromise. This patient is young and has no signs of compression, which favors a different diagnosis.

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Malignant cells in an amyloid stroma:
Incorrect: Malignant cells in an amyloid stroma is characteristic of medullary thyroid carcinoma. This tumor is composed of a malignant proliferation of parafollicular С cells, which secrete calcitonin. Calcitonin deposits within the tumor as amyloid. Familial cases are often due to multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A and 2B. In contrast, this young patient with a history of radiation and no other features of MEN syndrome more likely has papillary carcinoma.

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Malignant proliferation of follicles that invade the capsule:
Incorrect: Malignant proliferation of follicles that invade the capsule is characteristic of follicular carcinoma. Identification of capsular invasion is essential in distinguishing follicular carcinoma from follicular adenoma, wherein the neoplastic cells are separated from the nearby tissue by an intact capsule. However, since fine needle aspiration only examines the cells and not the capsule, this finding would be unlikely.

Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Malignant cells with nuclear clearing and indentations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Normal cells with fibrosis that extend to local structures:
Incorrect: Normal cells with fibrosis that extend to local structures is characteristic of Riedel thyroiditis. Chronic inflammation leads to extensive fibrosis, leading to a hard, non-tender goiter. There also may be local compressive features such as dysphagia or hoarseness. This young patient with a history of radiation, a discrete thyroid nodule, and no features of local compression more likely has papillary carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of a 12-lb weight gain over the past two months. The patient is a vegetarian and her diet consists of fruits, vegetables, and grains. She has had no increase in appetite. The patient also complains of excessive fatigue but attributes it to her stressful job as a nurse. Three months ago, she experienced recurrent episodes of anxiety, palpitations, and unintentional weight loss of 8-lb; these episodes resolved on their own. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 52/min, blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg, and BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals cold, dry skin and thinning hair on the scalp. Neck palpation reveals no tenderness or masses. There is delayed tendon reflex relaxation in the lower extremities. Diagnostic testing shows the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   137 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride   99 mEq/L 
 Glucose  89 mEq/L 
 ESR  9 mm/hr 
 TSH  7.1 μU/mL 
 Anti-thyroid peroxidase   Positive 

BIopsy of this patient’s thyroid will most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration with germinal center formation and destruction of follicles
Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells
Empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing and dispersed concentric lamellar calcifications
Tall, crowded follicular cells with decreased colloid and peripheral scalloping
Obliterated follicles compressed by dense, fibrous, collagenous tissue

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with cold, dry skin, delayed tendon reflexes, and positive anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies. She most likely has Hashimoto thyroiditis.   

Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common form of autoimmune thyroiditis, as well as the most frequent cause of hypothyroidism in the United States. In this condition, B lymphocytes produce antibodies against thyroglobulin (Tg) and/or thyroid peroxidase (TPO), resulting in diffuse lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland. Since there is thyroid follicular cell destruction, there is occasionally an early episode of hyperthyroidism (e.g., anxiety, palpitations, weight loss) due to leakage of preformed T3 and T4, as seen in this patient. On histology, there can be Hürthle cells, which are also called oncocytes; these cells arise from the follicular epithelium and have an eosinophilic cytoplasm and a vesicular nucleus with a large nucleolus. There can also be lymphoid aggregates with germinal center formation.   





Option Analysis

✅ Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration with germinal center formation and destruction of follicles:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells:
Incorrect: This pathological finding is seen in subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (i.e. de Quervain thyroiditis). This condition may also present with initial hyperthyroidism (e.g., anxiety, palpitations, weight loss) due to the damaged thyroid follicular cells releasing preformed T3 and T4, followed by hypothyroidism due to granulomatous inflammation of the thyroid gland. A key characteristic finding of this condition, however, is a tender thyroid gland, which is not seen in this patient.
❌ Empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing and dispersed concentric lamellar calcifications:
Incorrect: This pathological finding is consistent with papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. The “empty-appearing nuclei” describe the Orphan Annie nuclei, which are characteristic of papillary carcinoma. Additionally, the dispersed concentric lamellar calcifications describe psammoma bodies. Patients with papillary carcinoma usually present with a painless thyroid mass and have normal TSH levels. In contrast, this patient has no thyroid masses and an elevated TSH, making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Tall, crowded follicular cells with decreased colloid and peripheral scalloping :
Incorrect: This pathological finding is characteristic of Graves disease, which is a form of hyperthyroidism. Patients form autoantibodies to the TSH-receptors on the thyroid gland, which leads to thyroid gland overstimulation. The resulting activation of follicular cells induces reabsorption of stored colloid (giving rise to the pathognomonic, diffuse scalloping seen on biopsy) as well as production and release of T3 and T4. 
❌ Obliterated follicles compressed by dense, fibrous, collagenous tissue:
Incorrect: This biopsy finding is consistent with Riedel thyroiditis, which is another form of autoimmune thyroiditis. In this condition, there is invasive fibrous growth in the thyroid, often extending into neighboring organs. The condition can present as a hard, enlarged thyroid and cause symptoms secondary to compression (e.g., dysphagia, dyspnea). The patient’s clinical symptoms are not consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the clinic due to anxiety. Over the past few months, the patient has felt more stressed and has had an occasional feeling that his heart was racing, which he attributed to work stress. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland is noted. Examination of the patient’s lower extremities reveals the following finding:

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following will most likely be seen on histological examination of the patient’s thyroid gland if a biopsy is performed?

choices.text: Tall, crowded follicular epithelial cells forming small papillae and scalloped colloid
Chronic inflammation with germinal centers and occasional Hurthle cells
Granulomatous inflammation, giant cells, and extravasation of colloid
Empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing and occasional calcifications

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with classic signs of hyperthyroidism including anxiety, tachycardia, palpitations, and diffuse goiter. Although laboratory tests are required for confirmation, the lower extremities show pretibial myxedema, a unique finding of Graves disease.  

Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, is an autoimmune condition caused by the production of autoantibodies to the TSH receptor (TRAb). These antibodies imitate the action of TSH and activate the receptor, leading to increased thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion, as well as a diffuse goiter (thyroid growth).  

Patients typically present with classic signs of hyperthyroidism, in addition to specific findings unique to Graves disease including periorbital edema, exophthalmos, and pretibial myxedema. Thyroid function tests typically show decreased TSH and elevated free T3 and T4 levels. In some patients only T3 is increased. Diagnosis can be made clinically in patients with obvious symptoms. In patients with more subtle presentations, measuring thyroid receptor antibodies and performing a thyroid nuclear scan can assist in diagnosis.  

Macroscopically, Graves disease is characterized by diffuse hypertrophy and hyperplasia of thyroid follicular cells. Microscopically, tall, crowded follicular epithelial cells forming small papillae and scalloped colloid are seen. In contrast to papillary carcinoma, the papillae lack fibrovascular cores. Germinal centers and lymphoid infiltrates consisting of predominantly T cells can be found throughout the interstitium.

Option Analysis

✅ Tall, crowded follicular epithelial cells forming small papillae and scalloped colloid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chronic inflammation with germinal centers and occasional Hurthle cells:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis, the most common cause of hypothyroidism. Patients usually present with fatigue, cold intolerance, constipation, weight gain, and bradycardia.
❌ Granulomatous inflammation, giant cells, and extravasation of colloid:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis, an inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland that usually follows a viral infection. It is characterized by neck pain, a tender goiter, and a predictable course of hyperthyroidism, then euthyroidism, hypothyroidism, and eventually restoration of normal thyroid function.
❌ Fibrosis and extracellular amyloid deposit:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Riedel thyroiditis, a manifestation of IgG4-related systemic disease. Patients usually present with a fixed, hard (rock-like), and painless goiter, as well as tracheal compression when the goiter becomes too large. Both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism may occur.
❌ Empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing and occasional calcifications:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with papillary thyroid carcinoma, the most common cancer of the thyroid. Patients usually present with a thyroid nodule rather than diffuse goiter and do not have signs of hyperthyroidism. On histology, it is characterized by cells with nuclear clearing (“Orphan Annie eye”), nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of an enlarging painless neck mass. She first noticed the mass 3 weeks ago and reports that it has gotten progressively larger over time. The patient has also gained 10-lb in the last 6 weeks, and frequently has to wear a sweater when taking a walk in the park, even on hot days. She has not experienced any night sweats or fevers. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 52/min, blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg, and BMI is 27 kg/m2. Palpation of the neck reveals a fixed, hard, painless goiter. There is delayed tendon reflex relaxation in the lower extremities. A biopsy of the mass is performed, which shows compression of follicles by extensive dense fibrous tissue. Laboratory studies are done and show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 ESR  6 mm/h 
 TSH  7.1 μU/mL 
 Anti-thyroid peroxidase   Negative 
 Anti-thyroglobulin antibody  Negative  
 
If left untreated, which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hypothyroidism (e.g., feeling cold on a hot day, weight gain), as well as an enlarging neck mass. Taking into consideration the biopsy findings showing fibrous tissue growth in the thyroid, this patient likely has Riedel thyroiditis (invasive fibrous thyroiditis).  

Although the etiology of Riedel thyroiditis is unknown, it is thought to be related to systemic conditions that affect immunoglobulin G4, such as autoimmune pancreatitis, retroperitoneal fibrosis, and noninfectious aortitis. Patients most commonly present with a slowly growing, painless neck mass. The progressive growth can impinge on nearby structures, leading to dysphagia (esophagus), dyspnea (bronchial compression), hoarseness (recurrent laryngeal nerves), and even hypocalcemia (parathyroid glands). Biopsy findings show infiltration of the thyroid with dense, fibrotic tissue. Although some cases resolve spontaneously, surgery is frequently indicated to relieve the compressive symptoms.    

 

Option Analysis

✅ Dysphagia from esophageal compression:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Metastasis to distant organs:
Incorrect: Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid is an extremely aggressive, poorly differentiated neoplasm of the thyroid. Biopsy would show undifferentiated giant cells, as well as discrete areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Clinical symptoms are usually related to mass effect, such as esophageal compression resulting in dysphagia and bronchial compression resulting in dyspnea. Although this patient’s presentation could be worrisome for anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, the biopsy results make this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Elevated calcitonin levels :
Incorrect: Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is classically seen in patients with MEN2 (RET gene mutation). Biopsy would show cells of C-cell origin, as well as amyloid in the stroma that stains with Congo red. Calcitonin is a hormone that is over-secreted by the neoplastic C-cells and is often used as a tumor marker to detect recurrence. This patient’s biopsy results suggest a different diagnosis. 
❌ Protrusion of the eyes:
Incorrect: Exophthalmos, or protrusion of the eyes, is commonly seen in patients with Graves disease. TSH autoantibodies stimulate retro-orbital fibroblasts to secrete glycosaminoglycans, which pull water into the interstitial space, resulting in protrusion of the eyes. This patient is presenting with signs of hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism, which therefore makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Non-Hodgkin lymphoma of the thyroid  :
Incorrect: Chronic autoimmune (Hashimoto) thyroiditis is currently the only known risk factor for primary thyroid lymphoma. Hashimoto thyroiditis is typically diagnosed by the presence of anti-thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies or anti-thyroglobulin (Tg) antibodies, neither of which are present in this patient.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to insomnia and anxiety over the past few months. The patient’s last menstrual period was 1 year ago, but she denies hot flashes or vaginal dryness. The patient notes that her hair has become fine lately, and she has been losing weight without intention. On physical examination, a non-tender, diffuse goiter is noted. Laboratory tests show low TSH and high free T3 and T4 serum levels. The physician suspects that the patient’s condition is due to the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Which of the following is the most specific finding for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, anxiety, goiter) which may be primary (e.g. Graves disease) or secondary (e.g. TSH secreting pituitary tumor). Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, and exophthalmos, periorbital and conjunctival edema, restriction of eye movement, and discrete locations of infiltrative dermopathy (pretibial myxedema) are findings specific to Graves disease.  

Graves disease is an autoimmune condition that is caused by the production of autoantibodies to the TSH receptor (TRAb) which activate the receptors and increase thyroid hormone synthesis. Graves orbitopathy is mediated by activation of TSH receptors and T cells in the retro-ocular space, which results in inflammation and accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAG). Likewise, pretibial myxedema occurs due to cytokine-mediated stimulation of fibroblasts, which in turn secrete GAG in the dermis.  

A patient presenting with new-onset ophthalmopathy, a large non-nodular thyroid, and signs hyperthyroidism has Graves disease. When the etiology of hyperthyroidism is not clear, the following tests can confirm the diagnosis of Graves disease:  

  • Measurement of TSH (thyrotropin) receptor antibodies (TRAb)  
  • Radioactive iodine uptake test (RAIU) showing diffusely increased uptake  
  • Measurement of thyroidal blood flow on ultrasonography  

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated creatine kinase levels:
Incorrect: Elevated creatine kinase levels are commonly seen in myopathies, including hypothyroid myopathy, but is rarely seen in hyperthyroid myopathy. Myopathy is not specific for Graves disease.
❌ Onycholysis:
Incorrect: Onycholysis, or loosening of the nails from the nail bed, can be seen in all causes of hyperthyroidism. It is not specific for Graves disease.
✅ Exophthalmos:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atrial fibrillation  :
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation can be seen in up to 20% of patients with hyperthyroidism, but it is not specific for any condition. It is more common in older patients.
❌ Myxedema:
Incorrect: Myxedema describes non-pitting edema. It is caused by infiltration of the skin with glycosaminoglycans and associated water retention. Although myxedema can be caused by Graves disease (pretibial myxedema), it can also be caused by hypothyroidism (generalized myxedema). Therefore, the presence of myxedema is not specific for this patient’s condition.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of excessive fatigue for the last 2 weeks. She states that 1 month ago, she had experienced episodes of palpitations and diarrhea, but those symptoms have now resolved. Past medical history is significant for type I diabetes mellitus, which is treated with insulin. She also has been taking a laxative several times a week to help with new-onset constipation, which started 3 weeks ago. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 48/min, blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg, and BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination shows cold, dry skin and thinning hair on the scalp. There is 1+ non-pitting edema on both lower extremities. Which of the following additional findings is likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Diffuse uptake of radioactive iodine on thyroid scintigraphy

questions.solution:
This middle-aged female is presenting with constipation, dry skin, thinning hair, and non-pitting edema in the lower extremities. She most likely has hypothyroidism. Taking into account the history of a previously diagnosed autoimmune condition (e.g. type I diabetes mellitus) as well as prior symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g. episodes of palpitations and diarrhea), she most likely has chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto thyroiditis).   

Hashimoto thyroiditis is the leading cause of hypothyroidism in the United States; it is autoimmune-mediated, and thus it tends to occur in patients with other underlying autoimmune conditions such as type I diabetes mellitus and vitiligo. Although the etiology is not fully understood, there is autoimmune-mediated lymphocytic inflammation and destruction of the thyroid tissue. This destruction of the follicular cells results in release of preformed thyroid hormones, which usually presents as an initial phase of hyperthyroidism. Patients subsequently progress to hypothyroidism as the thyroid parenchyma is destroyed and fibrosed.  

Diagnosis is based on thyroid function tests, as well as the presence of antibodies, such as anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-microsomal) and antithyroglobulin antibodies. Treatment is primarily with levothyroxine to replete the thyroid hormone deficiency.    



Option Analysis

✅ Positive antimicrosomal antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Human leukocyte antigen DQ8 positivity :
Incorrect: Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) DQ8 positivity is associated with celiac disease. Although this patient had episodes of diarrhea several weeks ago, the spontaneous resolution makes this diagnosis unlikely. This patient’s signs and symptoms make chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto thyroiditis) more likely, which is associated with HLA-DR5 positivity. 
❌ Decreased thyroid stimulating hormone levels:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., bradycardia, fatigue, hair thinning, non-pitting edema). The previous symptoms of palpitations and diarrhea were likely caused by autoimmune destruction of thyroid follicular cells and subsequent release of preformed T4 and T3. Therefore, the likely primary hypothyroidism seen in this patient would cause a resultant increase in thyroid stimulating hormone levels, not decrease. 
❌ Diffuse uptake of radioactive iodine on thyroid scintigraphy:
Incorrect: Thyroid scintigraphy is an imaging technique that demonstrates the structure and function of thyroid tissue based on the selective uptake of radioactive iodine (RAI). Normally, only the functional part of the thyroid gland takes up RAI. In patients with a hyperfunctioning thyroid gland (e.g. Graves disease), there would be an enlarged thyroid gland with diffuse uptake of RAI. However, in this patient currently presenting with hypothyroidism, there would be decreased uptake. 
❌ Positive TSH-receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: TSH-receptor antibodies are present in patients with Graves disease. The circulating TSH-receptor autoantibodies cause overstimulation of the thyroid gland, leading to excess production of thyroid hormone, resulting in signs of hyperthyroidism. In contrast, this patient is presenting with classical signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism, hence making Graves disease and the presence of TSH-receptor antibodies unlikely.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male comes to the emergency room because of severe lower-extremity cramping. The symptoms started three days ago. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, and he recently underwent surgery for a “thyroid problem.” He currently takes propranolol. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 141/78 mmHg. While the blood pressure is being measured in the left arm, spasms are noted in the patient’s left hand. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Blood tests and an electrocardiogram (ECG) are ordered. Which of the following findings will most like be observed on the patient’s ECG?

choices.text: Positive deflection at the J point

questions.solution:
This patient with severe lower extremity cramping after a recent thyroid surgery is most likely having hypocalcemia secondary to iatrogenic hypoparathyroidism. It is the most common cause of hypoparathyroidism, as thyroid surgery often leads to the damage and/or removal of the parathyroid glands. Another common cause is autoimmune destruction of the parathyroid glands.  

Hypoparathyroidism causes hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. These electrolyte derangements make neurons more excitable, which can trigger tetany and muscle spasms. Other findings include paresthesias, the Chvostek sign, which is when facial muscles twitch after the facial nerve is lightly tapped below the zygomatic process, and the Trousseau sign, which is when tightening of a blood pressure cuff causes muscle spasm in the wrist and hand (as seen in this patient). If the hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia are severe, life-threatening complications like seizures and cardiac arrhythmias can occur.  

Diagnosis is based on blood tests for parathyroid hormone, calcium, vitamin D, albumin, phosphorus, and magnesium. Also, an electrocardiogram might have changes such as a prolongedQT (see EKG below), prolonged ST segment, and arrhythmias, like torsade de pointes and atrial fibrillation.

 Figure 1: EKG with prolonged QT interval


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Flattened T waves:
Incorrect: Flattened T waves are observed in patients with hypokalemia. Hypokalemia can also present with muscle spasms and cramping. However, the patient’s history of recent thyroid surgery is concerning for hypocalcemia since the operation may damage or remove the parathyroid glands. Hypocalcemia does not typically present with flattened T waves. 
✅  QT-interval prolongation :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Peaked T waves:
Incorrect: Peaked T waves are observed in patients with hyperkalemia. The condition can present with arrhythmias and muscle weakness. However, it would be atypical for hyperkalemia to present with muscle spasms, and there are no conditions in the patient’s history (e.g., kidney disease, hypoaldosteronism, etc.) that would increase the risk of hyperkalemia. 
❌ Positive deflection at the J point :
Incorrect: An Osborn wave (a positive deflection at the J point) may be observed in patients with hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemia can present with bone pain, constipation, kidney stones, and altered mental status. However, the patient’s history of recent thyroid surgery is more concerning for hypocalcemia. 
❌ ST segment depression:
Incorrect: ST segment depression can be seen in conditions such as subendocardial ischemia, digoxin toxicity or hypokalemia. However, these conditions would not present with muscle spasms and cramps as observed in this patient.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to progressive neck swelling and discomfort over the past few months. She first noticed it after a viral infection, but she did not seek care as she thought it would self-resolve. She generally feels well, and medical history is unremarkable other than 2 C-sections at the ages of 31 and 33. Family history is non-contributory. She has not had palpitations, weight loss, or skin changes. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination, a non-tender goiter with an irregular surface is noted. The rest of the physical exam is within normal limits. Laboratory tests show low TSH and elevated free T3 and T4 serum levels. A radioactive iodine uptake test is performed, and the results are shown below:


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an irregular goiter, low TSH, and high thyroid hormones; she most likely has subclinical hyperthyroidism. The radioactive iodine uptake test (RAIU) shows multiple foci of increased uptake, which is consistent with the diagnosis of toxic multinodular goiter.  

Toxic multinodular goiter is characterized by the presence of multiple hyperfunctioning nodules (“hot”). Some patients may present with classic signs of hyperthyroidism such as tachycardia, sweating, fine hair, and a hand tremor, whereas others can be asymptomatic. On physical examination, multiple nodules can often be palpated.  

The pathogenesis involves somatic mutations in the TSH receptor signaling pathway, which enable follicular cells to secrete thyroid hormone independent of TSH stimulation. The elevated hormone levels increase negative feedback to the pituitary gland, which decreases TSH secretion. Ultrasound imaging can be used to detect the nodules, and RAIU will show multiple regions of increased uptake if the nodules are active. Treatment may include antithyroid drugs, radioiodine ablation, or surgery.


Option Analysis

❌ Toxic adenoma:
Incorrect: Toxic adenoma is a thyroid nodule that causes hyperthyroidism. Patients typically present with classic signs of hyperthyroidism in addition to a thyroid nodule found on physical examination or imaging. Laboratory values typically show low TSH levels and high free T3 and T4. Although toxic adenoma may present as subclinical hyperthyroidism as seen here, these radioactive iodine uptake test results favor another diagnosis. Also, on physical examination, a discrete nodule would be palpated rather than an irregular surface.  
✅ Toxic multinodular goiter:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis:
Incorrect: Subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis is an inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland that usually follows a viral infection. It is characterized by neck pain, a tender goiter, and a predictable course of hyperthyroidism, followed by euthyroidism, hypothyroidism, and eventually restoration of normal thyroid function. Laboratory values typically show low TSH levels and high free T3 and T4, as well as elevated CRP and ESR. A radioactive iodine uptake test will show decreased uptake rather than increased.
❌ Graves disease:
Incorrect: Graves disease is an autoimmune condition that is caused by the production of autoantibodies to the TSH receptor (TRAb), which stimulates the receptors and leads to increased thyroid hormone synthesis. Patients typically present with classic signs of hyperthyroidism, as well as exophthalmos and pretibial myxedema. Laboratory values typically show low TSH levels and high free T3 and T4. However, a radioactive iodine uptake test will likely show diffuse uptake rather than multiple foci. Also, on physical examination, the goiter is diffusely enlarged.
❌ Euthyroid sick syndrome:
Incorrect: Euthyroid sick syndrome is a condition characterized by low serum levels of thyroid hormones in clinically euthyroid patients with nonthyroidal systemic conditions. Laboratory values typically show low TSH, low T3 and T4, and elevated reverse T3.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to upper neck and jaw pain that started gradually a week ago. The patient is generally healthy, and medical history is unremarkable other than dysmenorrhea, for which she takes acetaminophen. Two weeks ago, she had an upper respiratory infection that resolved without treatment. During the past week, she has noticed that she sweats more than usual and has difficulty sleeping. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and very sensitive to touch. Laboratory tests are obtained and reveal the following:


Radioactive iodine uptake test is performed and reveals diffusely decreased uptake. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy patient is presenting with a painful and enlarged thyroid gland following a viral infection, as well as symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, sweating, insomnia). The laboratory results are also consistent with hyperthyroidism, showing low TSH and high free T3 and T4. Finally, the radioactive iodine uptake test shows diffusely decreased uptake, confirming the diagnosis of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain).  

Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis is an inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland that usually follows a viral infection. It is characterized by neck pain, a tender goiter, and a predictable course of hyperthyroidism, followed by euthyroidism, hypothyroidism, and eventually restoration of normal thyroid function. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein (CRP) are usually elevated.  

The majority of patients are treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or prednisone, although some patients with mild symptoms require no treatment. Propranolol may be added to patients who have bothersome symptoms of hyperthyroidism. Levothyroxine may be administered if the hypothyroidism phase is more pronounced.  


Option Analysis

❌ Circulating TSH receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: Circulating TSH receptor antibodies are present in patients with Graves disease. Patients with Graves hyperthyroidism can have neck pain or tenderness; however, the pain is much less severe than in subacute thyroiditis. Also, in Graves hyperthyroidism, radioactive iodine uptake is high, not low.
❌ Circulating thyroid peroxidase antibodies:
Incorrect: Circulating thyroid peroxidase antibodies are the pathogenesis behind Hashimoto thyroiditis (or antibodies to thyroglobulin or TSH-blocking antibodies). Hashimoto thyroiditis rarely causes pain.
✅ Granulomatous inflammation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Suppurative inflammation:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes acute infectious (or “suppurative”) thyroiditis and hemorrhage into a thyroid nodule. While both can present with severe thyroid pain, these abnormalities are predominantly unilateral. Moreover, a cyst is usually found on imaging in patients with acute infectious thyroiditis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician because of worsening muscle cramps for the past few weeks. The patient was adopted, and his family history is unknown. He failed to meet multiple cognitive and developmental milestones. Past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient does not have any history of infections. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 29/min and blood pressure is 103/72 mmHg. On the physical exam, the patient’s height is below the 5th percentile and weight exceeds the 90th percentile. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Examination of the bilateral hands reveals hypoplastic 4th and 5th digits. Gentle tapping anterior to the ear causes twitching of the lower facial muscles. Which of the following findings would most likely be observed on laboratory testing?
questions.solution:
In this vignette, a 5-year-old boy is presented with intellectual disability, developmental delay, obesity, short stature, short 4th/5th metacarpal bones with an acute complaint of muscle cramps. The examination finding of a positive Chvostek sign (gentle tapping anterior to the ear causes twitching of the lower facial muscles) is suggestive of hypocalcemia. This constellation of findings is termed Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO).  

AHO is frequently associated with pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a, an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the GNAS gene (encodes for a G-protein) that is transmitted by a mother to her offspring. Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a causes end-organ resistance to parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. The body tries to correct the serum calcium by releasing more PTH; thus patients also have elevated PTH levels.  

Blood tests will reveal hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia and increased PTH levels. In cases that are difficult to diagnose, biosynthetic PTH can be infused, and urinary excretion of phosphate can be monitored. Patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a will not have an increase in excreted phosphate. Lastly, genetic testing can be used to identify the GNAS mutation and confirm the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌   Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  ↑  ↑  ↓  :
Incorrect: This set of findings would be observed in primary hyperparathyroidism, which is usually due to parathyroid adenomas. Increased PTH release causes increased calcium uptake from the kidneys and intestines. Likewise, it reduces reuptake of phosphate in the kidneys. However, hypercalcemia would not account for the positive Chvostek sign observed in this patient.
❌    Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Normal Normal Normal :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory results would be observed in healthy individuals and those with pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism. In the latter case, individuals present with obesity, short stature, and hypoplastic 4th/5th fingers. However, patients with pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism have normal serum calcium levels. In contrast, this patient’s clinical findings are suggestive of hypocalcemia.
✅    Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  ↑  ↓ ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌    Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  ↓ ↓ ↑ :
Incorrect: A patient with hypoparathyroidism would present with this set of findings. Surgical resection (e.g., thyroidectomy, parathyroidectomy, etc.) is the most common cause of hypoparathyroidism in the United States. Hypoparathyroidism would account for the patient’s muscle cramps and spasms. However, it would not account for the developmental delays and hand abnormalities.
❌    Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  ↓ ↑  ↓  :
Incorrect: A patient with PTH-independent hypercalcemia would present with this set of findings. Excess calcium intake, vitamin D intake, and malignancies producing parathyroid-hormone related peptide can be the cause. None of these etiologies would explain the patient’s developmental delays and hand abnormalities.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of neck pain for the past week. The pain is located mainly in the neck, but states that it travels to the jaw at times. He experienced episodes of palpitations and anxiety-attacks for several weeks, which resolved spontaneously one week ago. Past medical history is significant for Crohn disease, which is well-managed with diet. The patient’s father had thyroid cancer at the age of 77. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg, and BMI is 20 kg/m2. Palpation of the neck causes severe pain for the patient. The thyroid gland is asymmetrically enlarged. Laboratory studies show the following:  

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   137 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride   99 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.6 mg/dL 
 Glucose  89 mEq/L 
 ESR  46 mm/h 
 TSH  6.8 μU/mL 
 Anti-thyroid peroxidase   Negative 
 Anti-thyroglobulin antibody  Negative  
 
A biopsy of the thyroid gland is performed and shows diffuse infiltration with lymphocytes and giant cells forming noncaseating granulomas, as well as disruption and collapse of thyroid follicles. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient had a previous episode of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, anxiety attacks), followed by an extremely tender neck mass, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism, and biopsy findings showing granulomatous inflammation of the thyroid. These findings are suggestive of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain thyroiditis).   

Although the exact mechanism is not yet established, subacute granulomatous thyroiditis is presumed to be caused by a viral infection. There are classically 3 stages to this condition, which are: 1) hyperthyroidism due to the extra thyroid hormones released by the damaged follicles, 2) hypothyroidism, and 3) return to a euthyroid state. Biopsy findings in the early phases will show neutrophils and destruction of follicles with colloid depletion, followed by formation of granulomas that surround the follicles.   

On clinical examination, the most common and consistent finding is severe neck pain, which can often radiate to the lower face, causing jaw pain. Since the underlying cause of this condition is inflammation, laboratory studies typically show an elevated ESR. The majority of cases resolve spontaneously after several weeks.  






Option Analysis

✅ A recent viral infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Biopsy showing vasculitic disease :
Incorrect: Certain types of vasculitis, such as temporal cell arteritis, can present with jaw pain and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Temporal cell arteritis, however, is almost exclusively seen in elderly women, which makes this diagnosis unlikely in this patient. 
❌ Recent flare-up of Crohn disease:
Incorrect: Crohn disease is an autoimmune inflammatory bowel disease characterized by granulomatous inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, resulting in chronic diarrhea and weight loss. However, Crohn disease would not cause granulomatous inflammation of the thyroid gland.
❌ Family history of thyroid cancer:
Incorrect: Thyroid cancers typically present as non-tender neck masses. Although this patient’s father had thyroid cancer, the age at which he developed the cancer makes it unlikely to be genetic in origin. In addition, the patient’s biopsy results are not consistent with a neoplastic process.
❌ Positive serology for thyroid-peroxidase autoantibodies:
Incorrect: Autoantibody production can result in hyperthyroidism (e.g. Graves disease) or hypothyroidism (e.g. Hashimoto thyroiditis). Although this patient had previous signs of hyperthyroidism (e.g., anxiety, palpitations), the tender neck mass and biopsy results point to another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old male comes to the clinic due to a neck lump that progressively enlarged during the past 2 months. The patient generally feels well but has recently been experiencing a worsening cough. Family history is unremarkable. The patient does not use tobacco, excessive alcohol, or illicit substances. He has no history of radiation. Vitals are all within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a distinct, palpable, non-tender nodule. Thyroid ultrasound results show a hypoechoic nodule with increased internal blood flow. Fine needle biopsy is obtained, and the results are shown below:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

After a discussion of the results, the appropriate treatment is initiated. Which of the following markers is the most specific for evaluating the treatment success in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a thyroid nodule that has suspicious features on ultrasound (hypoechoic with internal blood flow). The biopsy results reveal polygonal or spindle-shaped cells in an amyloid stroma, which is consistent with the diagnosis of medullary thyroid cancer (MTC).    

Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor of the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland, which produce calcitonin. The majority of cases are sporadic while the rest are hereditary as part of the multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) syndrome. In most cases of MTC, the disease has already metastasized by the time of diagnosis.
